member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.GetRoutingControlStateRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetRoutingControlState operation. Get the state for a routing control. A routing control is a simple on/off switch that you can use to route traffic to cells. When the state is On, traffic flows to a cell. When it's off, traffic does not flow.
Before you can create a routing control, you first must create a cluster to host the control. For more information, see CreateCluster. Access one of the endpoints for the cluster to get or update the routing control state to redirect traffic.
For more information about working with routing controls, see Routing control in the Route 53 Application Recovery Controller Developer Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.GetRoutingControlStateRequest.RoutingControlArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoutingControlArn.
The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) for the routing control that you want to get the state for.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.GetRoutingControlStateResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetRoutingControlState operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.GetRoutingControlStateResponse.RoutingControlArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoutingControlArn.
The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the response.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.GetRoutingControlStateResponse.RoutingControlState
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoutingControlState.
The state of the routing control.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.UpdateRoutingControlStateRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the UpdateRoutingControlState operation. Set the state of the routing control to reroute traffic. You can set the value to be On or Off. When the state is On, traffic flows to a cell. When it's off, traffic does not flow.
For more information about working with routing controls, see Routing control in the Route 53 Application Recovery Controller Developer Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.UpdateRoutingControlStateRequest.RoutingControlArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoutingControlArn.
The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) for the routing control that you want to update the state for.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.UpdateRoutingControlStateRequest.RoutingControlState
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoutingControlState.
The state of the routing control. You can set the value to be On or Off.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.UpdateRoutingControlStateResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the UpdateRoutingControlState operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.UpdateRoutingControlStatesRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the UpdateRoutingControlStates operation. Set multiple routing control states. You can set the value for each state to be On or Off. When the state is On, traffic flows to a cell. When it's off, traffic does not flow.
For more information about working with routing controls, see Routing control in the Route 53 Application Recovery Controller Developer Guide.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.AmazonRoute53RecoveryClusterClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing Route53RecoveryCluster
Welcome to the Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller API Reference Guide for Recovery Control Data Plane .
Recovery control in Route 53 Application Recovery Controller includes extremely reliable routing controls that enable you to recover applications by rerouting traffic, for example, across Availability Zones or AWS Regions. Routing controls are simple on/off switches hosted on a cluster. A cluster is a set of five redundant regional endpoints against which you can execute API calls to update or get the state of routing controls. You use routing controls to failover traffic to recover your application across Availability Zones or Regions.
This API guide includes information about how to get and update routing control states in Route 53 Application Recovery Controller.
For more information about Route 53 Application Recovery Controller, see the following:
You can create clusters, routing controls, and control panels by using the control plane API for Recovery Control. For more information, see Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller Recovery Control API Reference.
Route 53 Application Recovery Controller also provides continuous readiness checks to ensure that your applications are scaled to handle failover traffic. For more information about the related API actions, see Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller Recovery Readiness API Reference.
For more information about creating resilient applications and preparing for recovery readiness with Route 53 Application Recovery Controller, see the Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller Developer Guide.

member.name: M:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.AmazonRoute53RecoveryClusterClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonRoute53RecoveryClusterClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.AmazonRoute53RecoveryClusterClient.#ctor(Amazon.RegionEndpoint)
member.summary:

Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>
member.param: The region to connect.

member.name: M:Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.AmazonRoute53RecoveryClusterClient.GetRoutingControlState(Amazon.Route53RecoveryCluster.Model.GetRoutingControlStateRequest)
member.summary:
Get the state for a routing control. A routing control is a simple on/off switch that you can use to route traffic to cells. When the state is On, traffic flows to a cell. When it's off, traffic does not flow.
Before you can create a routing control, you first must create a cluster to host the control. For more information, see CreateCluster. Access one of the endpoints for the cluster to get or update the routing control state to redirect traffic.
For more information about working with routing controls, see Routing control in the Route 53 Application Recovery Controller Developer Guide.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetRoutingControlState service method.
member.returns: The response from the GetRoutingControlState service method, as returned by Route53RecoveryCluster.
member.exception: You don't have sufficient permissions to query the routing control state.
The cluster endpoint isn't available. Try another cluster endpoint.
There was an unexpected error during processing of the request.
The request references a routing control that was not found.
The request was denied because of request throttling.
There was a validation error on the request.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for GetRoutingControlState Operation

member.summary:
Get the state for a routing control. A routing control is a simple on/off switch that you can use to route traffic to cells. When the state is On, traffic flows to a cell. When it's off, traffic does not flow.
Before you can create a routing control, you first must create a cluster to host the control. For more information, see CreateCluster. Access one of the endpoints for the cluster to get or update the routing control state to redirect traffic.
For more information about working with routing controls, see Routing control in the Route 53 Application Recovery Controller Developer Guide.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetRoutingControlState service method.
A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the GetRoutingControlState service method, as returned by Route53RecoveryCluster.
member.exception: You don't have sufficient permissions to query the routing control state.
The cluster endpoint isn't available. Try another cluster endpoint.
There was an unexpected error during processing of the request.
The request references a routing control that was not found.
The request was denied because of request throttling.
There was a validation error on the request.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for GetRoutingControlState Operation

A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the UpdateRoutingControlStates service method, as returned by Route53RecoveryCluster.
member.exception: You don't have sufficient permissions to query the routing control state.
There was a conflict with this request. Try again.
The cluster endpoint isn't available. Try another cluster endpoint.
There was an unexpected error during processing of the request.
The request references a routing control that was not found.
The request was denied because of request throttling.
There was a validation error on the request.
